<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2BinFile:
```c
bool UtMem2BinFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        fwrite(Memory, Length, 1, fp);
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2BinFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2BinFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>

<target_code>

```c
if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the given fragment: the code calls the standard library function fopen, not UtMem2BinFile, so there is no direct or indirect recursion. A concrete violation scenario would be if fopen were replaced/overridden by a user-defined function or macro (e.g., custom_fopen) that (directly or transitively) called UtMem2BinFile; then UtMem2BinFile -> custom_fopen -> UtMem2BinFile would be an indirect self-call and would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2.
